Seeking Political Retribution

Trump has repeatedly vowed to seek political retribution against his opponents if returned to office, including threats to prosecute political rivals, target critics, and use the Justice Department for personal or political purposes. These statements have raised concerns about the potential for abuse of power and the undermining of democratic norms. Sources: NY Times, Washington Post

Trump pardoned political donors

Trump issued pardons to several wealthy individuals who had donated large sums to his campaign or political committees. Notable examples include:

  • Paul Pogue – Pogue’s family donated $238,541 to Trump Victory before his pardon for tax fraud. (ABC News)
  • Douglas Jemal – Donated $100,000 to the Republican National Committee in 2020 before his wire fraud pardon. (NY Times)
  • Michael Liberty – Donated to Trump’s campaign and Republican organizations before his pardon for illegal campaign contributions. (Bangor Daily News)
These actions raised concerns about the use of presidential clemency to reward political supporters.

Trump pardoned a major drug dealer

Trump granted clemency to Jonathan Braun, a convicted drug trafficker who ran a large-scale marijuana smuggling operation and was described by prosecutors as violent and threatening. The commutation was granted outside the usual DOJ process. Source: AP News

Trump pardoned January 6 rioters

Trump issued pardons to individuals convicted for their roles in the January 6 Capitol riot. Critics argue this sends a message that political violence is acceptable and will be forgiven if it serves Trump's interests, potentially encouraging future violence. Source: NY Times

Trump, Jan 6, ICE, and Controversial Actions

Key Points About Trump, Jan. 6, ICE, and Controversial Actions

Trump allies urging action on Jan. 6

Trump’s son Donald Trump Jr. and other allies texted or urged Trump’s team to get him to tell rioters to stop the January 6 attack, and conservative media figures and Republican officials pushed his chief of staff to intervene as the violence unfolded. Sources: PBS News, YouTube: Cheney reads texts to Meadows

Trump’s repeated claims the 2020 election was stolen

Despite about 60+ legal challenges being dismissed for lack of credible evidence, Trump continues to publicly assert the 2020 election was fraudulent and “stolen” without proof that has withstood judicial scrutiny. Sources: Christian Science Monitor, Wikipedia: Post-election lawsuits

Fox News and the 2020 election aftermath

Fox News faced a major defamation lawsuit (including Dominion Voting Systems’ ~$1.6 billion suit) claiming it amplified false election fraud narratives even as some hosts privately acknowledged those claims were unsubstantiated. Sources: PBS, GMA

Fed immigration enforcement & ICE shootings

Under the Trump administration’s expanded immigration enforcement (Operation Metro Surge), ICE and CBP agents in Minneapolis have fatally shot civilians during enforcement operations, including Renée Good and Alex Pretti. Sources: Wikipedia

Controversial federal immigration policing activity

State investigators in Minnesota reported being cut out of access to evidence in ICE-involved shootings, fueling criticism that federal control is blocking local accountability. Source: WRDW

Boats shot at in international waters

The Trump administration publicly shared video and statements claiming U.S. military strikes destroyed drug-carrying boats from Venezuela and saved American lives, but independent fact-checking outlets say there is no publicly provided evidence of what was aboard or how many lives were saved. Source: PBS Fact Check
